content: For the BS in Software Engineering on the Tucson main campus as an Arizona resident in 2025–2026, tuition is $865 per credit hour. A typical 15-credit semester costs about $12,975 in tuition, or $25,950 per year, plus about $1,731 in mandatory annual fees for a total of roughly $27,681 per year. Resident undergraduate tuition and fees are frozen again for 2025–26.

metadata.notes: No increase in resident undergraduate tuition and fees for 2025-26. University of Arizona has maintained same tuition rate for resident undergraduates for third consecutive year.

content: For the BS in Software Engineering on the Tucson main campus as a non-resident in 2025–2026, tuition is $1,683 per credit hour. A typical 15-credit semester costs about $25,245 in tuition, or $50,490 per year, plus about $1,731 in mandatory annual fees for a total of roughly $52,221 per year. Some students may qualify for reduced non-resident rates such as WUE.

metadata.notes: Out-of-state undergraduate tuition is significantly higher than in-state rates. Some students may qualify for reduced rates through Western Undergraduate Exchange (WUE) or other programs.

content: For the BS in Software Engineering through Arizona Online in 2025–2026, tuition uses a per-credit pricing model with the same rate for all students regardless of residency. Arizona residents have a tuition cap at 12 units in fall and spring, while non-residents do not. Students typically take 3–4 units per course and pay per credit, giving flexible pacing. Exact per-credit rates should be confirmed with Arizona Online or the Bursar’s Office.

metadata.note: Arizona Online charges same tuition rate for all students regardless of residency - no out-of-state tuition
metadata.tuition_cap_resident: Arizona residents have tuition cap at 12 units in Fall and Spring semesters
metadata.tuition_cap_nonresident: No tuition cap for non-resident students
metadata.additional_info: Specific per-credit rates vary by program level. Contact Arizona Online or Bursar's Office for exact rates.

content: For the MS in Software Engineering on the Tucson main campus as an Arizona resident in 2025–2026, tuition is about $937 per credit hour. With a 30-unit minimum program, estimated total tuition is around $28,110. Mandatory fees are approximately $835 per semester, or about $3,340 over four semesters, for an estimated total program cost around $31,450. Many working students take 1–2 courses per semester, with each 3-unit course requiring about 15 hours of work per week.

metadata.notes: Graduate students typically take 1-2 courses per semester if working full-time. Each 3-unit graduate course requires approximately 15 hours per week of work.

content: For the MS in Software Engineering on the Tucson main campus as a non-resident in 2025–2026, tuition is about $1,802 per credit hour. With a 30-unit minimum, estimated tuition is roughly $54,060, plus about $3,340 in mandatory fees across four semesters, for a total estimated program cost near $57,400. Many working students take 1–2 classes per semester.

metadata.notes: Graduate students typically take 1-2 courses per semester if working full-time.

content: The online MS in Software Engineering uses a per-credit pricing structure with the same rate for all students worldwide. The program requires at least 30 units. Arizona Online caps tuition for Arizona residents at 12 units in fall and spring; non-residents do not have a cap. Most working professionals take 1–2 three-unit courses per semester, finishing in roughly 3–4.5 years, though it can be completed faster. There is no additional exam beyond coursework for degree completion. Exact per-credit rates should be confirmed via the Bursar or Tuition Calculator.

metadata.tuition_structure: Per credit pricing - same rate for all students worldwide
metadata.tuition_cap_resident: Arizona residents enrolled in Arizona Online programs have tuition cap at 12 units in Fall and Spring semesters
metadata.tuition_cap_nonresident: No tuition cap for non-resident students
metadata.typical_completion_time: 3-4.5 years for students working full-time; faster for part-time students
metadata.course_load: Most online students working full-time take 1-2 courses per semester
metadata.notes: Arizona Online described as most affordable online software engineering degree among public universities (OnlineU.com). No additional exam required for MS completion - degree awarded after completing coursework with acceptable grades.
metadata.contact_for_rates: Contact Bursar's Office or use Tuition Calculator for exact per-credit rates

content: For the on-campus PhD in Software Engineering as an Arizona resident in 2025–2026, tuition is about $937 per credit hour. The program requires at least 63 units total, including 43 units of coursework, 18 dissertation units (SFWE 920), and 2 colloquium units (SFWE 695A). Coursework tuition alone is roughly $40,291 (43 × 937). Typical completion time is 4–6 years. Many PhD students receive funding packages that cover tuition and provide a stipend.

metadata.funding_opportunities: Research assistantships, teaching assistantships, fellowships may be available
metadata.notes: PhD students often receive funding packages that cover tuition and provide stipend. Contact graduate program for funding information.

content: For the on-campus PhD in Software Engineering as a non-resident in 2025–2026, tuition is about $1,802 per credit hour. The 43 coursework units correspond to an estimated $77,486 in tuition. Total program units remain 63 (including dissertation and colloquium). Many funded PhD students receive packages that cover tuition, often including the non-resident differential.

metadata.funding_opportunities: Research assistantships, teaching assistantships, fellowships may be available and often cover tuition differential
metadata.notes: PhD students often receive funding packages. Many funded PhD students receive resident tuition rate even if out-of-state.

content: The online PhD in Software Engineering uses a per-credit pricing model with the same rate for all students, regardless of residency. The degree requires at least 63 units (43 coursework, 18 dissertation, 2 colloquium, including 12 minor units). GRE is not required for admission. Typical completion time varies depending on work schedule and pacing. This option offers flexibility for working professionals; exact per-credit rates should be confirmed with the Bursar or Graduate College.

metadata.tuition_structure: Per credit pricing - same rate for all students worldwide
metadata.no_gre_requirement: GRE is not required for PhD admission
metadata.typical_completion_time: Variable depending on student's work schedule and pace
metadata.notes: Online PhD option provides flexibility for working professionals. Same degree and curriculum as on-campus program.
metadata.contact_for_rates: Contact Bursar's Office or Graduate College for exact per-credit tuition rates

content: Estimated room and board for students living on campus is about $9,575 per year for housing and $7,171 per year for meal plans, totaling roughly $16,746 per year. Off-campus costs vary by situation.

metadata.notes: These costs are for students living on campus. Off-campus living costs may vary.

content: Books and supplies typically cost between $1,000 and $2,000 per year, depending on program and course selection. Engineering and software engineering courses may require specific textbooks, software licenses, and computing equipment.

metadata.notes: Engineering and software engineering courses may require specific textbooks, software licenses, and computing equipment.

content: Students are expected to have a personal computer with webcam, microphone, and reliable internet access, especially for online courses. Some courses may require specific software or development tools, many of which are free or available through university licensing.

metadata.requirements: Personal computer with webcam, microphone, reliable internet access for online courses
metadata.software: Some courses may require specific software or development tools
metadata.notes: Many software development tools are available free or through university licensing.

content: Federal financial aid may include Pell Grants, Federal Direct Subsidized and Unsubsidized Loans, and Federal Work-Study. Students must be U.S. citizens or eligible non-citizens and submit the FAFSA each year using UA school code 001083.

types: Federal Direct Student Loans (Subsidized and Unsubsidized)
metadata.eligibility: Must be U.S. citizen or eligible non-citizen and submit FAFSA annually
metadata.notes: Federal Pell Grant automatically awarded to eligible students. Direct Student Loans must be accepted through UAccess Student Center.

content: The Arizona Promise Program covers remaining tuition and fee costs not met by other gift aid for eligible Arizona residents. It is income-based, requires full-time enrollment, and can last up to four years.

metadata.description: Covers remaining tuition and fee costs not covered by other gift aid for eligible Arizona residents
metadata.notes: Helps make University of Arizona accessible and affordable for Arizona residents with financial need.

content: Wildcat Tuition Awards are merit-based scholarships for Arizona residents, renewable annually for up to four consecutive years. Students finishing an undergraduate degree in less than four years may apply remaining semesters toward graduate tuition.

metadata.renewal: Renewable annually for four consecutive years
metadata.notes: Students completing undergraduate degree in less than four years may use remaining semesters toward graduate tuition.

content: Arizona Tuition Awards are merit-based scholarships for non-Arizona residents, including Arizona Recognition, Arizona Excellence, and Arizona Distinction Tuition Awards. They are renewable for four consecutive years and are highly competitive. Unused semesters can sometimes be applied toward graduate tuition.

metadata.eligibility: Non-Arizona residents, first-time full-time degree-seeking students, merit-based
metadata.notes: Highly competitive scholarships. Students completing undergraduate degree in less than eight semesters may use remaining semester(s) toward graduate tuition.

content: The Online Transfer Tuition Scholarship provides $500 per semester, renewable for up to three years or 60 UA credits, for students transferring from Arizona community colleges into Arizona Online programs.

metadata.duration: Renewable for up to three years or 60 University of Arizona credits
metadata.eligibility: Students transferring from Arizona community colleges to Arizona Online programs
metadata.notes: Provides clear path to bachelor's degree from University of Arizona Online.

content: Graduate assistantships include Research Assistantships (RA) and Teaching Assistantships (TA). They typically provide tuition coverage and a stipend and are awarded competitively by departments. Assistantships are a common funding source, especially for PhD students.

metadata.eligibility: Graduate students, competitive selection by departments
metadata.notes: Common funding source for graduate students, especially PhD students. Provides valuable professional experience.

content: Graduate fellowships offer competitive funding for students with exceptional academic records or research potential. Benefits can include tuition coverage and/or a stipend and may come from the Graduate College, departments, or external organizations.

metadata.description: Competitive funding for graduate students demonstrating exceptional academic achievement or research potential
metadata.benefits: Tuition coverage and/or stipend, varies by fellowship
metadata.notes: Available through Graduate College, departments, and external organizations. PhD students encouraged to apply.

content: The Tuition Payment Plan allows eligible students to divide tuition into smaller installment payments over the semester, helping make costs more manageable.

metadata.description: Allows students to divide tuition into smaller installment payments over time
metadata.notes: Helps make education more affordable by spreading payments throughout semester.

content: Many employers offer corporate tuition reimbursement benefits. Arizona Online students should check with their employer’s benefits department to see if tuition reimbursement is available.

metadata.description: Many employers offer tuition reimbursement benefits
metadata.notes: Arizona Online students should check with their benefits department about tuition reimbursement options.

content: Active duty military, veterans, and their families may use benefits like the Post-9/11 GI Bill, Yellow Ribbon Program, and Military Tuition Assistance. The University of Arizona is considered a military-friendly institution.

metadata.description: Benefits available for active duty military, veterans, and their families
metadata.notes: University of Arizona is military-friendly institution. See Active Military & Veterans page for details.

content: Resident undergraduate tuition is frozen for the 2025–2026 academic year, marking the third consecutive year with no increase in resident undergraduate tuition and mandatory fees.

metadata.details: Third consecutive year with no increase in resident undergraduate tuition and mandatory fees
metadata.announcement: Announced by President Suresh Garimella to maintain affordability and prevent financial barriers to education

content: The Net Price Calculator estimates a student’s actual cost of attendance by factoring in potential financial aid. It takes about 10 minutes to complete and requires basic financial and academic information.

metadata.description: Estimates actual cost of attendance including financial aid
metadata.url: Available on University of Arizona website
metadata.notes: Provides more accurate estimate than sticker price by factoring in potential financial aid.

content: The Tuition Calculator is UA’s official tool to calculate tuition and fees. It supports current and past tuition rates by campus location, college/program, academic level, and residency, and is the most accurate source for official tuition and fee info.

metadata.description: Official University of Arizona tool for calculating tuition and fees
metadata.features: Current and past tuition rates by campus location, college/program, academic career level, and residency
metadata.notes: Most accurate source for official tuition and fee information. Updated with Winter 2025 and Spring 2026 rates.

content: All tuition and fee amounts are subject to change without prior notice upon approval by the Arizona Board of Regents and may apply to current as well as incoming students. Always verify current rates with the Tuition Calculator or Bursar’s Office.

metadata.disclaimer: All tuition and fee amounts are subject to change without prior notice upon approval by Arizona Board of Regents (ABOR). Modifications may apply to currently enrolled students as well as incoming students.
metadata.verification: Always verify current rates using official Tuition Calculator or contact Bursar's Office.

content: In addition to base tuition, students may pay College of Engineering differential tuition or program fees, course-specific fees for labs, software, or equipment, and an Excess Hours Tuition Surcharge if they exceed 145 undergraduate credit hours. Course fees are listed in the Schedule of Classes.

metadata.college_fees: College of Engineering may assess additional differential tuition or program fees
metadata.course_fees: Some courses may have additional fees for lab materials, software, or special equipment
metadata.excess_hours: Undergraduate students with more than 145 credit hours may be assessed Excess Hours Tuition Surcharge
metadata.notes: Refer to Schedule of Classes for course-specific fees.

content: International students must demonstrate English proficiency (e.g., TOEFL, IELTS, PTE, Duolingo). Conditional admission may be available for students who meet all requirements except English proficiency, and CESL offers English-training courses. International students should also consider visa costs and international student fees.

metadata.english_proficiency_requirement: Must demonstrate English proficiency through TOEFL, IELTS, PTE, or Duolingo
metadata.conditional_admission: Available for students meeting all requirements except English proficiency
metadata.english_training: Center for English as a Second Language (CESL) courses available
metadata.notes: International students should also consider visa costs and international student fees.

content: The Bursar’s Office handles tuition and fee information, billing, and payment plans. Phone: 520-621-3232, Email: bursar@arizona.edu, Website: bursar.arizona.edu.

metadata.services: Tuition and fee information, billing, payment plans

content: The Office of Scholarships and Financial Aid provides information about financial aid, scholarships, grants, and loans, as well as help with FAFSA and aid applications. Website: financialaid.arizona.edu.

metadata.contact_information: Office of Scholarships and Financial Aid
metadata.fafsa_assistance: Help with FAFSA completion and financial aid applications

content: The Graduate College manages graduate admissions, degree requirements, and funding information. Website: grad.arizona.edu. Program-specific questions for ECE/Software Engineering typically go through departmental contacts, not the generic email here.

metadata.services: Graduate admissions, degree requirements, funding information

content: Arizona Online provides information on online programs, enrollment counseling, and tuition for online degrees. Each program has a dedicated enrollment counselor. Website: online.arizona.edu.

metadata.services: Online program information, enrollment counseling, tuition for online programs
metadata.dedicated_counselors: Each online program has dedicated enrollment counselor

content: Arizona residency status is critical for tuition. The Registrar’s Office handles residency classification, and students can apply for reclassification if their circumstances change. Residency is defined by specific criteria and significantly affects tuition cost.

metadata.arizona_resident_definition: Students must meet specific criteria to be classified as Arizona residents for tuition purposes
metadata.reclassification: Students may apply for residency reclassification if circumstances change
metadata.notes: Residency status significantly affects tuition costs. Students should verify their classification and appeal if necessary.

content: Through the Western Undergraduate Exchange (WUE), eligible students from participating western states may receive a reduced tuition rate of 150% of the Arizona resident tuition rate. Software Engineering may be eligible; students should confirm with admissions.

metadata.description: Program allowing students from western states to receive reduced tuition
metadata.eligible_states: Western states participating in WUE program
metadata.eligible_majors: Software Engineering may be eligible - check with admissions
metadata.notes: Significant savings compared to full out-of-state tuition.

content: The Systems and Industrial Engineering department may offer scholarships specifically for Software Engineering students. Students should check with the department and complete scholarship applications by the posted deadlines.

metadata.software_engineering: Systems and Industrial Engineering department may offer scholarships
metadata.application: Check with department and complete scholarship applications by deadlines
metadata.notes: Engineering students encouraged to apply for department and college-specific scholarships.

content: External scholarships from organizations like National Merit, Hispanic Scholarship Fund, Society of Women Engineers, and NSBE can significantly reduce costs. Students are responsible for finding and applying to these scholarships.

metadata.description: Scholarships from outside organizations, foundations, and corporations
metadata.application: Students responsible for finding and applying to external scholarships
metadata.notes: Can significantly reduce cost of attendance. Students should research and apply broadly.

content: For an Arizona resident in BS Software Engineering living on campus, the estimated annual cost of attendance is about $27,681 in tuition and fees, $16,746 in room and board, roughly $1,500 for books and $2,000 for personal expenses, totaling around $47,927 per year (about $191,708 over four years). Actual costs vary based on housing, lifestyle, and aid.

metadata.notes: Actual costs vary based on housing choice, lifestyle, and financial aid received.

content: For a non-resident in BS Software Engineering living on campus, the estimated annual cost of attendance is about $52,221 in tuition and fees, $16,746 in room and board, roughly $1,500 for books and $2,000 for personal expenses, totaling around $72,467 per year (about $289,868 over four years). Merit aid and Arizona Tuition Awards can significantly reduce costs.

metadata.notes: Actual costs vary. Merit scholarships and Arizona Tuition Awards can significantly reduce costs for out-of-state students.

content: For an Arizona resident MS Software Engineering student, the total program tuition and fees are estimated around $31,450 for 30 units over 2–2.5 years. Books and supplies add roughly $2,000–$3,000, and living expenses vary. Total estimated program cost is around $34,000–$40,000, though many students receive assistantships or fellowships.

metadata.living_expenses: Variable - many students work while completing degree
metadata.notes: Many graduate students receive assistantships or fellowships that cover tuition and provide stipends.

content: For a typical Arizona resident graduate student in 2025–2026, the official cost of attendance lists about $12,700 in tuition and fees, $16,800 for housing and food, $600 for books, $5,000 for travel, and $5,100 for miscellaneous, for a total around $40,200 per year. Minimum direct educational costs (tuition plus books) are about $13,300.

metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Full COA includes all estimated living expenses. Minimum costs represent only direct educational expenses.

content: For a non-resident graduate student in 2025–2026, the official cost of attendance lists about $23,400 in tuition and fees, $16,800 for housing and food, $600 for books, $5,100 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous, totaling roughly $48,400 per year. Minimum direct educational costs are about $24,000.

metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Full COA includes all estimated living expenses. Minimum costs represent only direct educational expenses.

content: For a first-year or transfer Arizona resident living with a parent in 2025–2026, the official undergraduate COA lists about $13,900 for tuition and fees, $3,050 for housing and food, $600 for books, $2,400 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous expenses, for a total of roughly $22,450 per year.

metadata.official_coa_undergraduate: First-Year/Transfer Student - Arizona Resident - Living with Parent
metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Lowest cost option for Arizona residents. Living at home significantly reduces housing and food costs.

content: For a first-year or transfer Arizona resident living on campus in 2025–2026, the official COA lists about $13,900 for tuition and fees, $17,300 for housing and food, $600 for books, $2,400 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous expenses, totaling roughly $36,700 per year.

metadata.official_coa_undergraduate: First-Year/Transfer Student - Arizona Resident - On-Campus Housing
metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Includes on-campus housing and meal plan costs.

content: For a first-year or transfer Arizona resident living off campus in 2025–2026, the official COA lists about $13,900 for tuition and fees, $12,750 for housing and food, $600 for books, $2,400 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous expenses, totaling roughly $32,150 per year.

metadata.official_coa_undergraduate: First-Year/Transfer Student - Arizona Resident - Off-Campus Housing
metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Off-campus housing typically less expensive than on-campus but more than living with parents.

content: For a first-year or transfer non-resident living on campus in 2025–2026, the official COA lists about $43,100 for tuition and fees, $17,300 for housing and food, $600 for books, $2,400 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous expenses, totaling roughly $65,900 per year.

metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Non-resident tuition significantly higher. Includes on-campus housing and meal plan.

content: For a first-year or transfer non-resident living off campus in 2025–2026, the official COA lists about $43,100 for tuition and fees, $12,750 for housing and food, $600 for books, $2,400 for travel, and $2,500 for miscellaneous expenses, totaling roughly $61,350 per year.

metadata.source: University of Arizona Official Cost of Attendance
metadata.notes: Off-campus housing option for non-resident students.

content: UA’s Cost of Attendance (COA) represents average living and student expenses for the academic year and is based on student surveys and resources like the Consumer Price Index. Direct costs include tuition, fees, and books, while indirect costs include housing, food, travel, and miscellaneous expenses. Students are encouraged to create their own budget.

metadata.description: The estimated Cost of Attendance (COA) lists average living and student expenses likely to be incurred during the academic year (fall and spring semesters)
metadata.calculation_method: Dollar amounts calculated by surveying current Arizona students and using other resources including the Consumer Price Index
metadata.direct_costs: Tuition, fees, books, course materials - billed directly to student account
metadata.indirect_costs: Housing, food, travel, miscellaneous - not billed by university but estimated expenses
metadata.budgeting_importance: Students should prepare own budget as part of successful financial plan
metadata.variation: Actual expenses may be higher or lower depending on individual circumstances

content: Federal loan fees vary depending on how much a student borrows and only apply to students taking out federal student loans.

metadata.note: Federal Loan Fees will vary depending on a student's exact loan amounts
metadata.application: Only applies to students taking out federal student loans

content: College fees vary by program. Engineering students may have specific College of Engineering fees, so it’s important to check with the program and Bursar’s Office for exact amounts.

metadata.note: College Fees will vary depending on a student's program
metadata.application: Engineering students may have specific College of Engineering fees
metadata.verification: Check with specific program and Bursar's Office for exact fees

content: Many PhD Software Engineering students are funded. A typical funding package includes full tuition coverage plus a stipend via a research or teaching assistantship. Out-of-pocket costs are usually limited to certain fees and living expenses beyond the stipend.

metadata.stipend_range: Variable based on assistantship type and department
metadata.tuition_coverage: Research or Teaching Assistantship typically covers tuition
metadata.out_of_pocket_costs: Minimal - primarily fees and living expenses beyond stipend
metadata.notes: Most PhD students receive funding packages. Competitive applicants often fully funded throughout program.
